G. L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction under Massachusetts law over custody and modification proceedings.

G. L. c. 209B (UCCJEA).proposition: This Court has jurisdiction under Massachusetts law over custody and modification proceedings.

Mass. R. Dom. Rel. P..proposition: The court may also order interim relief and modifications that preserve the children’s safety and stability pending a full hearing.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 119, \u00a7 51A.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 119, § 51A (mandatory reporting of suspected child abuse or neglect) (procedural importance where safety concerns arise);

Custody of a Minor, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, modification of a custody/care arrangement requires a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the existing order that affects the best interests of the child.
Custody of a Minor, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is not Custody of a Minor, 385 Mass. 91 (1982), but a landlord-tenant/emotional distress case involving Gem Realty and Solomon. It concerns warranty of habitability, quiet enjoyment, emotional distress, and statutory damages under G.L. c. 186, § 14, not custody or modification standards. It nowhere addresses custody, care arrangements, or any requirement of a material and substantial change in circumstances; therefore it does not support the stated proposition about Massachusetts custody modification law.
Custody of a Minor, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: We affirm the judgments entered for Solomon on her claims for breach of the warranty of habitability, reckless infliction of emotional distress, and attorneys’ fees. We also affirm the judgment entered for Gem on Solomon’s claim of negligence. We vacate the $10,000 award for interference with quiet enjoyment.

McWeeney v. McWeeney, 28 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: McWeeney v. McWeeney, 28 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (1990)
McWeeney v. McWeeney, 28 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, modification of a custody/care arrangement requires a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the existing order that affects the best interests of the child.
McWeeney v. McWeeney, 28 Mass. App. Ct..case_name: J & R Investment, Inc. v. City Clerk
McWeeney v. McWeeney, 28 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion deals entirely with subdivision control law, constructive approval of an ANR plan under G.L. c. 41, § 81P, and the appropriate remedy (mandamus vs. § 81BB appeal). It does not concern family law, custody, or modification of care arrangements, nor does it discuss any standard involving a material and substantial change in circumstances or best interests of a child. Therefore, it provides no authority for the proposition about custody modification under Massachusetts law.
McWeeney v. McWeeney, 28 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: This is an appeal from a partial summary judgment in favor of the plaintiffs... [regarding] their claim that they had the right to have a plan of certain land they owned in New Bedford endorsed “approval under the subdivision control law not required” in accordance with G. L. c. 41, § 81P... In view of the planning board’s failure to act within the time limit, the plaintiffs had the right to the requested endorsement on the plan.

Palmiero v. Palmiero, 40 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Palmiero v. Palmiero, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (1996)
Palmiero v. Palmiero, 40 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, modification of a custody/care arrangement requires a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the existing order that affects the best interests of the child.
Palmiero v. Palmiero, 40 Mass. App. Ct..case_name: Mansfield v. Commissioner of the Department of Public Welfare
Palmiero v. Palmiero, 40 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether there was sufficient state action in the reduction of Medicaid personal care benefits to trigger due process hearing rights. It does not address custody or care arrangements for children, nor does it discuss any standard for modification such as a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting a child’s best interests. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition about custody modification under Massachusetts law.
Palmiero v. Palmiero, 40 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: We affirm the ruling of the judge that State action was involved and that the plaintiff was entitled to a hearing concerning the reduction in her benefits. Contrary to the Department’s contention, Blum v. Yaretsky, supra, does not foreclose this result.

LaFleur v. LaFleur, 447 Mass. 719 (2006).proposition: The court’s paramount concern is the best interests of the child—evaluating the child's safety, welfare, stability, and developmental needs and the ability of each parent to care for the child.
LaFleur v. LaFleur, 447 Mass. 719 (2006).support_reasoning: This is a Massachusetts criminal case about withdrawal of guilty pleas and ineffective assistance of counsel in a murder prosecution. It does not involve child custody, parenting plans, or any articulation of the "best interests of the child" standard. The opinion focuses on voluntariness of pleas, adequacy of counsel, and evidentiary issues, so it does not support the claimed proposition about the court’s paramount concern being the best interests of the child.

D'Amico v. D'Amico, 396 Mass. 579 (1985).proposition: The court’s paramount concern is the best interests of the child—evaluating the child's safety, welfare, stability, and developmental needs and the ability of each parent to care for the child.
D'Amico v. D'Amico, 396 Mass. 579 (1985).support_reasoning: The opinion is a commercial contract and Chapter 93A business dispute; it does not involve custody, visitation, or any child-related determinations. Nowhere does the court discuss the best interests of a child, or evaluate child safety, welfare, stability, developmental needs, or the parenting abilities of the parties. Therefore this case cannot be cited as authority for the proposition about the court’s paramount concern being the best interests of the child.
D'Amico v. D'Amico, 396 Mass. 579 (1985).relevant_excerpt: [No relevant excerpt available. The opinion concerns a dispute over the sale and operation of a magazine subscription business and related contract and G.L. c. 93A claims, and contains no discussion of child custody, visitation, or best interests of the child.]

Branch v. Branch, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (1.raw_text: Branch v. Branch, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (1983)
Branch v. Branch, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (1.proposition: The court’s paramount concern is the best interests of the child—evaluating the child's safety, welfare, stability, and developmental needs and the ability of each parent to care for the child.
Branch v. Branch, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (1.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about a defendant’s competency to stand trial, not a family-law or custody case. It does not discuss custody standards, parental abilities, or the best interests of a child, nor does it articulate any principle that the court’s paramount concern is the child’s best interests. Therefore it does not support the claimed proposition.
Branch v. Branch, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (1.relevant_excerpt: The narrow issue is whether at any time prior to the return of the guilty verdict there was “a substantial question of possible doubt” about the defendant’s competency to stand trial... When such a question arises, the trial judge must, on his own initiative, conduct a full hearing on the issue.

Porreca v. Porreca, 399 Mass. 724 (1987).proposition: Massachusetts caselaw makes clear that changes in parental employment or availability that materially affect parenting time and the child’s welfare can justify modification of custody/parenting time.
Porreca v. Porreca, 399 Mass. 724 (1987).case_name: Gill v. Board of Registration of Psychologists
Porreca v. Porreca, 399 Mass. 724 (1987).support_reasoning: This decision involves a psychologist’s attempt to resign his professional license and the requirement to exhaust administrative remedies before seeking judicial review. It does not concern child custody, parenting time, parental employment, or changes in parental availability. Therefore, it provides no authority for the proposition that changes in parental employment or availability can justify modification of custody or parenting time in Massachusetts.
Porreca v. Porreca, 399 Mass. 724 (1987).relevant_excerpt: We have long followed the rule that “[i]n the absence of a statutory directive to the contrary, the administrative remedies should be exhausted before resort to the courts.” East Chop Tennis Club v. Massachusetts Comm’n Against Discrimination, 364 Mass. 444, 448 (1973)... In this case, the board has not had the opportunity to consider the plaintiff’s argument.

Crawford v. Crawford, 45 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Crawford v. Crawford, 45 Mass. App. Ct. 202 (1998)
Crawford v. Crawford, 45 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts caselaw makes clear that changes in parental employment or availability that materially affect parenting time and the child’s welfare can justify modification of custody/parenting time.
Crawford v. Crawford, 45 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: This is a criminal appeal from rape and indecent assault convictions and contains no discussion of custody, parenting time, modification standards, or the impact of parental employment/availability on child welfare. The opinion focuses on evidentiary issues, sufficiency of evidence for forcible rape, and jury instructions. It therefore does not address, much less establish, the family-law proposition claimed.
Crawford v. Crawford, 45 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: On his appeal from convictions by a jury on indictments charging him with forcible rape of a child and indecent assault and battery on a child under fourteen, the defendant argues that the trial judge erred in excluding evidence of the victim’s prior false allegation of rape and, with respect to the indictment charging forcible rape, in denying his motion for a required finding of not guilty, and in instructing the jury. We affirm the convictions.

Fenton v. Fenton, 426 Mass. 293 (1997).proposition: Massachusetts caselaw makes clear that changes in parental employment or availability that materially affect parenting time and the child’s welfare can justify modification of custody/parenting time.
Fenton v. Fenton, 426 Mass. 293 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt provided is a Massachusetts criminal case about murder, intoxication, Miranda waivers, and jury instructions on malice and deliberate premeditation. It does not concern family law, custody, parenting time, or modification standards. Therefore, it does not establish or discuss the principle that changes in parental employment or availability justifying modification of custody or parenting time, and cannot support the cited proposition.
Fenton v. Fenton, 426 Mass. 293 (1997).relevant_excerpt: We have reviewed the record as a whole and have found no further reason to exercise our extraordinary power under G. L. c. 278, § 33E, to order a new trial or to reduce the verdict to involuntary manslaughter. There is no miscarriage of justice in convicting the defendant of murder in the second degree, nor is a verdict of involuntary manslaughter more consonant with justice.

Ferguson v. Ferguson, 34 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Ferguson v. Ferguson, 34 Mass. App. Ct. 123 (1993)
Ferguson v. Ferguson, 34 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts caselaw makes clear that changes in parental employment or availability that materially affect parenting time and the child’s welfare can justify modification of custody/parenting time.
Ferguson v. Ferguson, 34 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The case Ferguson v. Ferguson, 34 Mass. App. Ct. 123 (1993), as provided here, is an insurance coverage/snowmobile case and does not concern family law, custody, parenting time, or modification standards. It addresses whether a snowmobile is a ‘motor vehicle’ for compulsory uninsured motorist coverage purposes. Because it does not discuss parental employment, availability, or child welfare in any custody context, it cannot support the claimed proposition about modification of custody/parenting time.
Ferguson v. Ferguson, 34 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: "This appeal raises the issue whether a snowmobile is a motor vehicle for purposes of compulsory uninsured motorist coverage. We conclude that it is not, except possibly when it is being used on a public way."

Custody of a Minor (No. 1), 400 Mass. 55.proposition: Massachusetts caselaw makes clear that changes in parental employment or availability that materially affect parenting time and the child’s welfare can justify modification of custody/parenting time.
Custody of a Minor (No. 1), 400 Mass. 55.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about murder and rape of a child and addresses grand jury issues, admissibility of expert testimony, sufficiency of the evidence, and G. L. c. 278, § 33E review. It does not concern custody, parenting time, parental employment or availability, or modification of custody orders. Therefore it provides no authority for the proposition about changes in parental employment justifying modification of custody or parenting time.
Custody of a Minor (No. 1), 400 Mass. 55.relevant_excerpt: We have reviewed the whole case on the law and the facts, and we determine that there is no substantial likelihood that a miscarriage of justice has occurred... There was ample evidence from which the jury could conclude that the child was a victim of sexual abuse, that her death resulted from such abuse, and that it was the defendant, the only person with her at the time, who inflicted the trauma that caused her death. We see no reason to grant relief under G. L. c. 278, § 33E.

Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 344 (1983).proposition: The court may also order interim relief and modifications that preserve the children’s safety and stability pending a full hearing.
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 344 (1983).support_reasoning: The opinion is a tort and conflicts-of-law decision about negligent infliction of emotional distress and breach of warranty in the context of an airplane crash. It does not involve child custody, interim relief, or any orders designed to preserve children’s safety or stability pending a full hearing. Nothing in the reasoning or holding addresses a court’s authority to issue interim custody or protective orders, so it cannot be cited as authority for that proposition.
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 344 (1983).relevant_excerpt: In summary, in answer to the questions certified to this court, on the facts as submitted to us, we conclude that the law of Massachusetts applies to both the plaintiff’s breach of warranty and negligence claims and that, under Massachusetts law, the plaintiff is not entitled to recover damages under either of these theories.

Lerner v. Lerner, 431 Mass. 256 (2000).proposition: The court may also order interim relief and modifications that preserve the children’s safety and stability pending a full hearing.
Lerner v. Lerner, 431 Mass. 256 (2000).support_reasoning: This opinion concerns the constitutionality of certain electric utility charges and tax classifications under Massachusetts and federal law. It does not involve domestic relations, custody, or any discussion of interim relief or temporary orders to preserve children’s safety or stability. Therefore it provides no authority for the proposition about interim relief in child-related proceedings.
Lerner v. Lerner, 431 Mass. 256 (2000).relevant_excerpt: No excerpt in this opinion addresses interim relief, temporary orders, or preservation of children’s safety or stability pending a full hearing. The case is focused on whether statutory charges imposed on customers of investor-owned utilities constitute reasonable excise taxes and comply with equal protection requirements.
